questions.text: Which of the following is not a natural estrogen?
questions.solution:
Ethinylestradiol is a synthetic estrogen.

Natural estrogens are:

  • Estradiol
  • Estriol
  • Estrone

questions.text: A  55-year-old postmenopausal lady is on estrogen as part of her hormone replacement therapy. Which of the following statements about estrogen is not true?
questions.solution:
Estrogen causes an increase in plasma HDL levels.

Estrogen also causes an increase in triglycerides, apolipoprotein levels, and an increase in the turnover of LDL receptors.

questions.text: A post-menopausal lady who is on estrogen therapy for hot flashes is concerned about its adverse effects. She is not at an increased risk of developing which of the following cancers?
questions.solution:
Women receiving estrogen therapy do not have an increased risk of developing gall bladder carcinoma.

Long-term estrogen therapy can increase the risk of gall stones. Although gall stones can be associated with the development of gall bladder carcinoma, there is no direct correlation between long term estrogen therapy and gall bladder carcinoma.

Estrogen therapy has been associated with breast, endometrial and hepatocellular carcinoma.

questions.text: In which of the following conditions is hormone replacement therapy not helpful?
questions.solution:
Hormone replacement therapy(HRT) is not helpful in coronary heart disease. 

Progesterone used in the HRT is associated with an increased risk of coronary artery disease, thromboembolism, and related mortality. Estrogens promote coagulation and thromboembolic episodes.

Options A and B: Estrogen is helpful in flushing and local preparations are preferred for vaginal atrophy.

Option D: Estrogen is beneficial for osteoporosis if it is started before the onset of significant osteoporosis.

Note: The use of HRT for cardiovascular benefits is quite controversial. The current consensus is that the HRT should be started only after assessing the benefit/risk profile individually and is not indicated for the prevention of cardiovascular events in all menopausal women as it was previously advocated.

questions.text: Progestin dose remains constant throughout the cycle in which of the following type of combined contraceptive pills?
questions.solution:
Monophasic pills contain constant amounts of progesterone and estrogen that is taken daily for 21 days, followed by a 7-day pill-free period.

Biphasic and triphasic pills have variable amounts of active ingredients (especially progesterone) that mimic the natural changes in the hormonal levels in the menstrual cycle. These pills reduce the total amount of steroids that needs to be administered.

questions.text: A young lady who is on oral contraceptive pills refrains from taking any drug even for minor ailments due to the fear of contraceptive failure. Which of the following drugs can be taken safely?
questions.solution:
Among the given drugs, aspirin use is least likely to cause contraceptive failure.

Option B: Broad-spectrum antibiotics like tetracycline suppress the intestinal flora and interfere with the enterohepatic circulation of estrogen. This leads to lowering of plasma estrogen levels and can result in contraceptive failure.

Options C and D: Enzyme inducers like phenytoin and rifampicin increase the metabolism of oral contraceptives and can cause contraceptive failure.

questions.text: A 23-year-old lady has been on anti-epileptic therapy since childhood and now comes to the OPD seeking advice on a suitable method of contraception. Which contraceptive method should be avoided in her?
questions.solution:
Oral contraceptives must be avoided or used cautiously in epilepsy.

The most important aspect to consider is the drug interactions between anti-epileptic drugs and contraceptives. There is no conclusive evidence on whether estrogen is beneficial or harmful for seizure control. 

Note: Convulsive disorder is not an absolute contraindication; it is safe to avoid but can be used with caution.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about oral contraceptive pills is true?

choices.text: It is protective against ovarian cancer
OCP are used in treatment mastalgia
Rifamipicin decreases the metabolism of OCP

questions.solution:
Oral contraceptive pills (OCP) protect against ovarian cancer. 

This benefit is thought to be due to the prolonged suppression of gonadotropin stimulation of the ovary on long-term use of OCPs. 

Other benefits of oral contraceptive pills:

  • Lesser incidence of endometrial carcinoma due to progestin component in OCP
  • Regularisation of menstrual cycles results in relief of dysmenorrhea and menorrhagia
  • Reduced incidence of fibrocystic breast disease and ovarian cysts
  • Endometriosis and pelvic inflammatory disease are improved

Option A: The estrogen component of combined oral contraceptive pills is mainly responsible for venous thromboembolism.

Option C: OCP is not used in the treatment of mastalgia. Mastalgia, chloasma, and breakthrough bleeding are known side effects of oral contraceptive pills.

Option D: OCPs are metabolized by CYP3A4 enzymes. Rifampicin is a strong inducer of CYP3A4. Hence, if administered together, rifampicin can cause enhanced metabolism of OCPs and may lead to contraceptive failure.

questions.text: A 23-year-old lady on oral combined contraceptive pills misses a single dose and reports to you in the OPD the next morning. What will be the most appropriate advice to this patient?

choices.text: Continue taking the next dose as scheduled
Double the next dose to make up for the missed dose
Interrupt the course and start taking the medications again on 5th day of bleeding
Start a fresh course of OCP again

questions.solution:
The most appropriate advice for this patient who has missed a single dose of the oral contraceptive pill (OCP) is to double the next dose to make up for the missed dose.

Missed dose considerations for oral combined contraceptive pills:

  • If a single dose is missed - a double dose can be taken on the next day to make up for the missed dose.
  • If two or more doses are missed on subsequent days - the last missed pill has to be taken along with the present pill and alternative methods of contraceptive must be used for the next 7 days.
  • If the pills were missed on the last week (days 15-21) - omit the hormone-free interval by finishing the hormonal pills in the current pack and starting the new pack from the next day.

questions.text: In which of the following patients is combined oral contraceptive pills not absolutely contraindicated?

choices.text: A perimenopausal woman with coronary heart disease
A 23-year-old lady with a past history of hepatic adenoma
A multiparous lady with abnormal undiagnosed vaginal bleeding

questions.solution:
A migraine headache is a relative contraindication for the use of combined oral contraceptives. Migraine with focal neurological symptoms is an absolute contraindication to combined oral contraceptive use.

Absolute contraindications to combined oral contraceptive use:

  • Presence or history of thromboembolic disease, cerebrovascular disease, myocardial infarction, coronary artery disease
  • Congenital hyperlipidemia
  • Known or suspected carcinoma of the breast, female reproductive tract
  • Known or suspected pregnancy
  • Past or present liver tumors or impaired liver function
  • Undiagnosed vaginal bleeding.
  • Migraine with focal neurological symptoms

Relative contraindications to combined oral contraceptive use:

  • Migraine headaches in >35 yrs female
  • Hypertension
  • Diabetes mellitus
  • Obstructive jaundice of pregnancy
  • Prior oral contraceptive use
  • Gallbladder disease

questions.text: Progestin-only pills do not act by which of the following mechanisms?

choices.text: Eliciting an inflammatory action in the endometrium

questions.solution:
Copper intrauterine devices elicit an inflammatory reaction within the endometrium. This impairs sperm viability, motility, and fertilization.

All the following actions contribute to the contraceptive action of progestin-only pills:

  • The effectiveness of this drug is largely due to the thickening of cervical mucus which in turn impair sperm penetration.
  • Inhibits ovulation via exerting negative feedback on the hypothalamus (GnRH). This leads to the absence of the FSH and LH surge, which is essential to mature the dominant follicle and trigger ovulation.
  • Interfere with the implantation of a zygote by altering the endometrial environment. 

The major reason women discontinue the use of progestin-only contraceptives is breakthrough bleeding.

questions.text: A 35-year-old lady, P2L2, has been taking depot medroxy progesterone acetate as a contraceptive. Which of the following best describes the formulation?
questions.solution:
Depot medroxyprogesterone acetate (DMPA) is a long-acting progestin-only injection formulation.

DMPA is administered every 3 months intramuscularly as a contraceptive.

questions.text: Which of the following progesterone is used in emergency contraception?
questions.solution:
Levonorgestrel is the progesterone that is used in emergency contraception. Levonorgestrel-containing regimens are considered the standard regimen now.

Option B: Micronised progesterone is indicated for amenorrhea and to counteract estrogen effects on the uterus.

Option C: Norgesterone is usually used along with ethinyl estradiol for regular contraception.

Option D: Depot medroxyprogesterone acetate is a long-acting depot preparation indicated for long-term contraception.

questions.text: A newly married couple came to the OPD saying that they had unprotected intercourse two days back but are not desiring a baby at present. Which of the following drugs can be prescribed in this case?
questions.solution:
Ulipristal is a selective progesterone receptor modulator (SPRM) that can be given as an emergency contraceptive in this case.

It should be administered within 5 days of unprotected intercourse.

It inhibits ovulation by suppressing LH surge as well as by direct effect on follicular rupture. In addition, its action on the endometrium can interfere with implantation.

In November 2020, DCGI directed the termination of manufacture, sale, and distribution of ulipristal acetate 5mg due to case reports of liver injury.

questions.text: The standard emergency contraceptive pill regimen, levonorgestrel can be taken up to how many hours after unprotected intercourse?
questions.solution:
Levonorgestrel regimen can be taken within 72 hours after unprotected intercourse but is most effective when taken as early as possible.

Levonorgestrel for emergency contraception can be taken as either of the following:

  • 2 tablets of 0.75 mg 12 hours apart
  • 1.5 mg single-dose

questions.text: A 20-year old lady came to the OPD with complaints of missed period. You diagnose her to be 5 weeks pregnant but she is not willing to continue the pregnancy. You decide to prescribe her a drug that has anti-progestational activity. Which of the following drugs would you choose?
questions.solution:
Mifepristone (RU-486) has potent anti-progestational (abortive activity) and significant anti-glucocorticoid and antiandrogenic activity.

Options A and B: Levonorgestrel and desogestrel are progesterone preparations.

Option C: Misoprostol is a synthetic prostaglandin (PGE1) preparation.

questions.text: In the treatment of which of the following patients will you not consider clomiphene citrate?

choices.text: A 48-year old perimenopausal woman with hot flashes

questions.solution:
Clomiphene citrate is not used in the treatment of hot flashes.

Option A- Clomiphene increases gonadotropin secretion and stimulates ovulation. It mainly acts by blocking the inhibitory actions of estrogen on gonadotropin release from the pituitary gland. It is primarily indicated in the management of infertility.

Option C - In men also, clomiphene increases gonadotropin secretion and promotes spermatogenesis. However, success rates are low.

Option D - Studies have shown clomiphene citrate to be effective in treating and preventing short-lasting unilateral neuralgiform headache attacks (SUNCT). It has not yet been FDA-approved for the treatment of SUNCT.

questions.text: A 45-year-old lady, diagnosed with breast cancer, is started on a selective estrogen receptor modulator. Identify the drug.
questions.solution:
Raloxifene is a selective estrogen receptor modulator. 

It has agonist action on bone and antagonist action on the breast and uterus.

It is used in the treatment and prevention of osteoporosis and in breast cancer prevention in high-risk postmenopausal women.

questions.text: A 60-year-old lady who is on tamoxifen, for the treatment of breast cancer is worried about its side effects. Which of the following side effects of tamoxifen is least likely to occur in this patient?
questions.solution:
Tamoxifen acts as an estrogen receptor antagonist in breast tissues. The use of tamoxifen in carcinoma of breast patients decreases the incidence of carcinoma in opposite breasts.

The estrogen agonistic action of tamoxifen and its consequences are:

  • Uterine endometrium - endometrial hypertrophy, vaginal bleeding, and endometrial cancer 
  • Coagulation system - thromboembolism leading to pulmonary embolism (tamoxifen decreases the level of antithrombin III and protein C in the blood)
  • Bone metabolism - increase in bone mineral density
  • Liver - alterations of blood lipid profile
  • Cataract

questions.text: Which of the following is a selective estrogen receptor down regulator?
questions.solution:
Fulvestrant is a selective estrogen receptor down-regulator. It does not have estrogen agonistic activity for any tissue and is regarded as a pure estrogen antagonist.

Tamoxifen, toremifene, and raloxifene are selective estrogen receptor modulators with the agonist or antagonist action at different tissues.

questions.text: Which of the following is an aromatase inhibitor?
questions.solution:
Exemestane is an aromatase inhibitor.

Estrogen is locally produced from androgen by the action of the aromatase enzyme. Locally synthesized estrogens play an important role in the development of breast cancer because they are estrogen-dependent for proliferation.

Aromatase inhibitors decrease estrogen synthesis and are widely used now in the treatment of breast cancer in postmenopausal women.

Aromatase inhibitors are:

  • Letrozole
  • Anastrozole
  • Exemestane (Irreversible inhibitor)

questions.text: You decide to change the chemotherapeutic regimen of a patient with breast cancer from tamoxifen to an aromatase inhibitor. Which of the following is not an advantage of the latter in the treatment of breast cancer?

choices.text: No increase in risk of venous thromboembolism
No increase in risk of endometrial cancer
Can be used in advanced cases which are tamoxifen-resistant

questions.solution:
Aromatase inhibitors lack the property of maintaining bone mineral density when compared to tamoxifen.

Aromatase inhibitors dramatically reduce estrogen levels that result in a decrease in the risk of venous thromboembolism and also decreases the risk of endometrial hyperplasia/cancer. It is also indicated in tamoxifen-resistant advanced breast cancer.

questions.text: Yuzpe's regimen of emergency contraception consists of which of the following?
questions.solution:
Yuzpe's regimen of emergency contraception consists of a combination of levonorgestrel and ethinylestradiol.

The regimen includes two doses at 12 hours intervals within 72 hours of unprotected intercourse. It has a higher incidence of nausea and vomiting and is less efficacious than progesterone only standard regimen.

Methods of Emergency contraception:

Drug Dose
Levonorgestrel 0.75mg stat and after 12 hours
Ethinyl estradiol 50 μg + Norgestrel 0.25 mg 2 tab stat and 2 tab after 12 hours
Conjugated estrogen 15 mg BD x 5 days
Ethinyl Estradiol 2.5 mg BD X 5 days
Copper IUDs Insertion within 5-7 days after accidental unprotected exposure.Not suitable for rape victims
Centchroman 2 tablets(60 mg) to be taken twice at an interval  of 12 hours within 24 hours of intercourse.
Ulipristal 30 mg within 120 hours

questions.text: You are an intern posted in the medicine ward and you notice the given dermatological finding in a patient with abdominal distension. Which of the following hormones is implicated in this finding?
questions.solution:
The image shown is of spider nevus and the hormone implicated in its development is estrogen. 

It is commonly seen in hyperestrogenic states such as pregnancy and in those taking estrogen-containing contraceptives. It can also be seen in male patients with cirrhosis due to the decreased ability of the liver to metabolize circulating estrogens, specifically estrone, which derives from the androgen androstenedione. Estrogens cause blood vessels to enlarge and dilate.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old man presents to the OPD with the following condition. Which of the following drugs can cause this adverse effect?

1. Clomiphene citrate
2. Tamoxifen
3. Spironolactone
4. Ketoconazole
5. Chlorpromazine
questions.solution:
This is a case of gynecomastia which can occur as an adverse effect of spironolactone or ketoconazole or chlorpromazine. 

Spironolactone - decreases testosterone production, increases peripheral conversion of testosterone to estradiol, and displaces estradiol from their plasma-protein-binding sites

Ketoconazole - decreases testosterone production and displaces testosterone from their binding sites

Chlorpromazine (neuroleptics) - increase prolactin release by blocking the inhibitory action of dopamine on prolactin

Clomiphene and tamoxifen are used mainly in reducing male gynecomastia.
